text: Patient: If, if, if, if – Doctor: So, if the hormones alone are making those get better, better, better, we give you the trial, I have no way to know did it do anything. So, we usually wait until the hormone stops working by itself. Family Member: And, that’s all just gauged by a PSA or do you do the – Doctor: It’s gauged by PSA as a screening and then, you know, at some point we would then just re-image you, too. Family Member: Hmm. Doctor: But, our experience is, as long as the PSA’s going down, usually the imaging is either getting better or staying stable. So. Patient: If the PSA is that reliable in terms of – Doctor: Ehhh, it’s reliable enough. I don’t know, it’s not unbelievably reliable, but Patient: But, if – Doctor: Rather than, you know, trying to give you a CAT scan every month. Patient: It’s, it’s, it’s unlikely that the PSA is going to go up if things are okay. Doctor: Yes.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. It comes with side effects because it’s never nothing without nothing. Patient: What is the side effects? Doctor: Number one, two and three is tiredness. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And tiredness isn’t that your brain isn’t functioning, functioning great. Patient: Just physically tired? Doctor: Physically tired and it’s a weirder tired not like you worked out in the yard for twelve hours and can’t do much, it’s just no get up and go. If that happens, we take a break and we reduce the medicine dose. Patient: Let me ask you something doc. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Can we, can we provide a pill that would give me a little, like a vitamin that would give me a little energy? Doctor: No I think the issue of you not having as much energy is that your cancer is starting to, sorry that your thing is starting to break through slowly, Patient: Right.

text: Patient: - going down and coming back, and, uh, my daughter said you don’t seem like you feel anything. I said, no, I feel pretty good there. And, uh, so I do have those particular days, but then I have those days as well. I said, oh, man, when this day going to be over with so I can go to bed tonight Doctor: Is that because of pain that those days are hard for you? Patient: Sometimes it’s, it’s pain, but a lot of the areas that I wasn’t haven’t pain in, uh, not much anymore. My heel on my left side was having a lot of pain that I think I had shared, and, uh, I still have some if I go and overdo it, but other than that, no, my shoulders every now and then. My biggest challenge now is, is getting a good night’s sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And that’s because I’ve tried a number of different ways on how to sleep in the bed. I, I have these pillows that I prop up with a long pillow there, to try to lean up against the back of it so, I, you know, my back is up against the pillow. It works some nights. Some nights it doesn’t work. Doctor: Okay. And so you’re having trouble falling asleep or is it that you fall asleep and then you, you’re waking up with-? Patient: Well, I wake back up. And sometimes if, uh, you know how you try to get in a comfortable position? It’s trying to find that comfortable position for that night. Doctor: So you’re waking up because of pain? Patient: Uh, not pain all the time. Sometimes it’s just, uh, what’s the term I’m looking for? Doctor: Discomfort? Patient: Yeah. You know? And, uh, just trying to get in a place where you feel like this is where I need to be at, I’m happy here. So, uh, uh, one of the best sleeping place, and I hate to say it, is my living room downstairs on the couch. I prop the pillows up, and, uh, and got my favorite space, so when I lay down and put my back up right up against the back of it, but I don’t want to be in the business of sleeping on my living room couch every night, either. We have a sleep number bed that we purchased just for this, but, uh, uh, I wouldn’t recommend sleep number being if that’s what you’re going, you’re going to use it for, because it’s not all it’s, it’s cut out to be. You’re paying a lot of money for a bed. And sometimes it works, sometimes it don’t. So my biggest challenge each night is to figure out, okay, what’s going to work tonight? Is my Lazy Boy going to work? Uh, I even tried the floor with my granddaughter’s, uh, what do you call those things she has? Family Member: The bean bag. Patient: The bean bags. That was the worst idea I ever had. When I got in that bean bag, uh, I, I was in pain. And the bad part is I couldn’t get back out of the, get out of the bean bag, and get off the floor.

text: Patient: Yeah I was. Doctor: So they had to give you a lot of fluids. So your doctor’s pretty, pretty worried. Your, your lungs, you know, they’re already not great with the cancer but then you had pneumonia on top of that, so. Well, we’ll get those records to make sure that’s, and you know, kind of what ended up happening because they couldn’t give me anything until you were discharged. So now that you’re discharged for a couple of days, they’ll send that up, up to us. Patient: Yeah, Uh the last time they gave me something to take home, antibiotics, some kind of antibiotics to take home, that just I didn’t get nothing. Doctor: Okay. You didn’t get some this time? Okay. So it might have been more flu. Yeah. Okay. So, I’ll, I’ll have M___ come in and say hello and then we’ll have you come back here in a couple of weeks and let’s, let’s run through it. Awesome. text: Patient: And he’s said he’s had good luck with other patients that have had pain with that Cymbalta. Doctor: In the joints? I mean I don’t know how it will help with that with your pain, but you know what it’s definitely worth a try. I have no objections to giving that a try but I’m not terribly hopeful, but if he’s seen something different in his experience. Patient: Well if that’s the case I’ll just stay on the prednisone. Forget that. I mean it’s not something Doctor: Okay I mean I’m okay if you want to give that a try Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: and there’s no objection or problem - Patient: Okay. Doctor: from the study standpoint. Patient: Alright, Okay. Family Member: Which is the lesser of the two evils as far as taking it long term? I’m not familiar with Cymbalta. Doctor: Well, I think Cymbalta is probably you know much more proven you know long term. The steroids can have other issues of you know blocking the immune systems likely increased risk of infections and things like that over the long term, but you know it’s – I kind of think it’s unlikely that it will help arthritic pain. If it is neuropathic nerve pain and stuff, you know Cymbalta can be effective. Patient: Yeah I think that’s what he said also yeah. Doctor: I don’t think that is the reason for your pain, but that’s my impression.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: But when you’re on pills like that, experimental ones – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You don’t want to have some big surgery, be scheduled in the middle of it. Doesn’t make sense. Because you have to do one at a time. Patient: I got you. Doctor: Because it’s a big sur – I mean it’s a big one. (Cell phone rings) Patient: So let me ask you this here, doc. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Do people come out of that surgery? Doctor: Oh, yeah! They do! (Cell phone rings) Patient: Right. Doctor: But it’s a start. So, what does that tell us? It’s aggressive, but we know that about your cancer. But, if we don’t talk about surgery as an option, then we didn’t do right by you because you know that that’s a possibility. What’s the root of all that? Well, it’s your cancer not controlled. That’s always the root of all evil. Not your bones, but your lymph nodes are growing. So, in this –

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
